commit_message:
Add disk dev name check function

This patch will add new function in extend_start.sh for OSD
creation. Not only support loop device but also others that
disk dev layout is end with numbers.

Change-Id: Iee5f8b8581d70166de6eba1bdc9e42766fe8cb48
Closes-Bug: #1847014

subject: Revert "Use tenancity to backoff when layer is locked"
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3153, 'name': 'Emilien Macchi', 'email': 'emilien@redhat.com', 'username': 'emilienm'}, {'_account_id': 6926, 'name': 'Bogdan Dobrelya', 'email': 'bdobreli@redhat.com', 'username': 'bogdando'}, {'_account_id': 9712, 'name': 'Dougal Matthews', 'email': 'dougal.matthews@canonical.com', 'username': 'dougal'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 28223, 'name': 'Cedric Jeanneret', 'display_name': 'cjeanner (Tengu)', 'email': 'cjeanner@redhat.com', 'username': 'cjeanner'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-10-14 15:02:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-10-14 15:08:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-10-14 15:34:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

NOTE: this is only to restore from the regression.

If we want to see less "Layer is being fetched by another worker" messges logged for each locked layer, let's increase the sleep time. But making it waiting until a condition is met does not stack good with an exponential backoff IMO. Ofc, we could try to implement that for like a 1h or so, but that anyway should be a separated tenacity decorator and another exception type'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-10-15 12:31:35.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bug/1844446-patch2 to lock_stock_barrels'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-10-15 15:20:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2019-10-16 13:15:20.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

That endless waiting seen in the timed out OVB jobs was probably caused bu that "fixed" exit condition. Apparently "keep retrying until we no longer have collisions" was not the best strategy :)

I'm not sure which should be the exit condition then. I leave that for the authors of the involved changes.'}]

commit_message:
Revert "Use tenancity to backoff when layer is locked"

Make it really "keep retrying until we no longer have collisions".
This fixes the introduced regression where tenacity might
stop retrying after some limit values, and the originally coded exit condition would be violated then to exit before we actually no longer can have colliding locks.

Closes-Bug: #1819175

This reverts commit 98f2d962f955fd57085f6c2a9fcc3882f9eaae38.

Change-Id: I87f5b73fdd77c94ebfe0d3c5a8c06a81b8f2e3ec

commit_message:
Slim down the pre-built DIB IPA images

* Move remove-extra-packages to post-install since finalise.d
  is running on the final image and the DIB documentation
  recommends avoiding unnecessary actions there.
* Remove a few packages that used to be removed only for Fedora;
  do not try to remove those that aren't on the cloud image.
* Do all uninstallations in pre-install phase, so that it doesn't try
  to remove dependencies of already installed packages.
* Exclude more locale files from the image.
* Exclude the content of /var/log.

Change-Id: Idb7819b1d783f4f5f390cc7621019d3be2fa576f

subject: Move ironic-lib.filters to etc/ironic/rootwrap.d
messages:
[{'account_id': 7102, 'date': '2019-09-25 15:01:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2019-09-26 13:59:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Thanks. I'm wondering if anything is assuming the original location, but hoping/guessing not."}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2019-09-27 07:44:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

this type of files are by default "per project", their locations depend on rootwrap.conf, the correct path is under /etc/ironic/rootwrap.d/
if anything breaks because of this change, then the path in the configuration must be changed to the one here'}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2019-09-30 15:47:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Riccardo. The path is configurable [1] (or supposed to be). Whether anyone configures it, I don't know.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/src/commit/0d1a929f9e94fc453ce81bec5b2804d4cfb557d0/ironic/conf/default.py#L333"}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2019-10-01 07:14:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> @Riccardo. The path is configurable [1] (or supposed to be).
 > Whether anyone configures it, I don't know.
 > 
 > [1] https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/src/commit/0d1a929f9e94fc453ce81bec5b2804d4cfb557d0/ironic/conf/default.py#L333

Hey Ruby, this is a different thing.
What's configurable there is the rootwrap configuration file path, while this patch is about the filters file path.
I don't think the latter is configurable."}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2019-10-16 13:08:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@Riccardo. The path to the rootwrap.conf file is configurable. And the rootwrap.conf file itself, includes a config that specifies the filter path: https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/src/commit/a2ae57c457962e6fa5e590c0de19f4d457637881/etc/ironic/rootwrap.conf#L7'}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2019-10-16 13:11:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> @Riccardo. The path to the rootwrap.conf file is configurable. And
 > the rootwrap.conf file itself, includes a config that specifies the
 > filter path: https://opendev.org/openstack/ironic/src/commit/a2ae57c457962e6fa5e590c0de19f4d457637881/etc/ironic/rootwrap.conf#L7

Yes, of course it's configurable inside rootwrap.conf, I meant just not directly configurable by any option in ironic :)"}]

commit_message:
Move ironic-lib.filters to etc/ironic/rootwrap.d

This is the path where ironic searches for rootwrap filter files by
default.
This is important because ironic itself is going to remove [1] its
copy of the ironic-lib.filters file.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/684270

Change-Id: I2241bfd11c66fb84b8840ab76563af52fe93e5ad

commit_message:
Add nodegroup CRUD commands

The commands added are:

* openstack coe nodegroup create <params> <cluster> <nodegroup>
* openstack coe nodegroup delete <cluster> <nodegroup>
* openstack coe nodegroup update <op> <params> <cluster> <nodegroup>

Depends-On: I4ad60994ad6b4cb9cac18129557e1e87e61ae98c
Change-Id: I98b662b5a95f16d80852e3b30683c75e78acb3e5

commit_message:
Ensure tunnel types are absent if not configured

This patch fixes a bug where updating a configuration wouldn't remove
agent/tunnel_types configuration when required.

Change-Id: I8248ad80e6ff88aec252919fa687018bda78a60b
Closes-Bug: #1832251
(cherry picked from commit 6c34ce2a42ae8c445a1fbe14ab18d4ee59e09c9b)

commit_message:
Remove need to configure VF during DPDK deployment

The current configuration expects VF & bonding info by default. This patch
set removes the need to configure them for every deployment.

Change-Id: Id546c113b2d3c42591a0326ee8cd442cccc73578

subject: Never block or wait when workers upload images

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-04 15:59:30.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Be creative workers when uploading images

Multiple workers start in the creative mode and will cooperate and do not block
on locked layers. If layers locked, workers firstly will look for a free
layers, or free images. If there is no more retries in the budget, workers will
re-enter in the boring mode and will wait for the layer locks to release
meanwhile doing nothing useful.

This reimplements I477219b7dca1e6cfa02a278c55a0cc1a9833d007 in the locks-free
and non-blocking way, but also keeping the possibility to finish the undone
things using the traditional locks.

Related-Bug: #1844446
Change-Id: I1e1621537ed040548456a1699b972add1636e6ec
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

'}, {'created': '2019-10-07 15:51:49.000000000', 'message': 'WIP Be creative workers when uploading images

Multiple workers start in the creative mode and will cooperate and do
not block on locked layers. If layers locked, workers firstly will look
for a free layers, or free images.

This reimplements I477219b7dca1e6cfa02a278c55a0cc1a9833d007 in the
locks-free and non-blocking way.

Lower level changes explained:
* Extend layers locks management for images uploading as well
* Move locks management and the upload tasks function to the base image
  uploader class as the requirement of the former
* In the creative workers mode, increase minimum numbers of workers
  to a 4 and do not process the first image as a separate.
  Layers/images locking ensures no data races, when picking several
  images for concurrent processing.

Related-Bug: #1844446
Change-Id: I1e1621537ed040548456a1699b972add1636e6ec
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

'}, {'created': '2019-10-08 08:20:19.000000000', 'message': "Never block or wait when workers upload images

Multiple workers will not block on locked layers. If layers locked,
workers firstly will look for a free (unlocked) layers of the image
being processed, or another (unlocked) images.

This reimplements I477219b7dca1e6cfa02a278c55a0cc1a9833d007 in the
locks-free and non-blocking way. Locking both images and its layers
together with emoving exp-backoff sleeping of workers, when there is
collisions happen on layers allows running more concurrent workers
in the more efficient way (each worker always does some job and never
sleeps or blocks on something). Additionally that allows omitting
pulling the first image in a single worker mode, which also somewhat
speeds up the process. That is mainly because layers & images global
pool of locks ensures no data races, when picking several images for
concurrent processing, so a pair of workers will never end up pulling
the same layer, even it's contained by different images under
processing.

Lower level changes explained:
* Extend layers locks management for images uploading as well
* Move locks management and the upload tasks function to the base image
  uploader class as the requirement of the former
* Drop tenacity retrying on the collisions detected for layers/images
  as we do not need that any more and just raise for the worker to pick
  another layer or image to process
* Increase minimum numbers of workers to a 4 and do not process the
  first image as a separate.

Related-Bug: #1844446
Change-Id: I1e1621537ed040548456a1699b972add1636e6ec
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>
"}, {'created': '2019-10-08 13:17:26.000000000', 'message': "Never block or wait when workers upload images

"}, {'created': '2019-10-08 14:08:39.000000000', 'message': "Never block or wait when workers upload images

Multiple workers will not block on locked layers. If layers locked,
workers firstly will look for a free (unlocked) layers of the image
being processed, or another (unlocked) images.

This reimplements I477219b7dca1e6cfa02a278c55a0cc1a9833d007 in the
locks-free and non-blocking way. Locking both images and its layers
together with emoving exp-backoff sleeping of workers, when there is
collisions happen on layers allows running more concurrent workers
in the more efficient way (each worker always does some job and never
sleeps or blocks on something). Additionally that allows omitting
pulling the first image in a single worker mode, which also somewhat
speeds up the process. That is mainly because layers & images global
pool of locks ensures no data races, when picking several images for
concurrent processing, so a pair of workers will never end up pulling
the same layer, even it's contained by different images under
processing.

Lower level changes explained:
* Drop tenacity retrying on the collisions detected for layers/images
  as we do not need that any more and just raise for the worker to pick
  another layer or image to process
* Increase minimum numbers of workers to a 4 and do not process the
  first image as a separate.

commit_message:
Never block or wait when workers upload images

Multiple workers will not block on locked layers. If layers locked,
workers firstly will look for a free (unlocked) layers of the image
being processed, or another (unlocked) images.

This reimplements I477219b7dca1e6cfa02a278c55a0cc1a9833d007 in the
locks-free and non-blocking way. Locking both images and its layers
together with emoving exp-backoff sleeping of workers, when there is
collisions happen on layers allows running more concurrent workers
in the more efficient way (each worker always does some job and never
sleeps or blocks on something). Additionally that allows omitting
pulling the first image in a single worker mode, which also somewhat
speeds up the process. That is mainly because layers & images global
pool of locks ensures no data races, when picking several images for
concurrent processing, so a pair of workers will never end up pulling
the same layer, even it's contained by different images under
processing.

Lower level changes explained:
* Drop tenacity retrying on the collisions detected for layers/images
  as we do not need that any more and just raise for the worker to pick
  another layer or image to process
* Increase minimum numbers of workers to a 4 and do not process the
  first image as a separate.

Related-Bug: #1844446
Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/687294
Change-Id: I1e1621537ed040548456a1699b972add1636e6ec
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Increase the DIB DHCP timeout to 60

We seem to be hitting occasional failures to DHCP in time, although
DHCP itself seems working. Try increasing timeout from 30 to 60.

Change-Id: I0cc0af440f954007f01bae4508f6853e1529913d
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/684765

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-14 11:46:42.000000000', 'message': 'handle push error properly

If there was some error during pushing then Kolla was greeting with "all went
fine" message anyway:

INFO:kolla.common.utils.aodh-api:Trying to push the image
ERROR:kolla.common.utils.aodh-api:Get http://10.101.16.1:5000/v2/: dial tcp 10.101.16.1:5000: connect: no route to host
INFO:kolla.common.utils.aodh-api:Pushed successfully

This patch changes that. Now if there is an error during push then proper
exception is raised to PushTask and image is marked with PUSH_ERROR status.

This way at the end of build it is easy to spot which images did not got
pushed to registry:

Change-Id: Id2ab97bf4c0dc3423268a0ea435b56f4a65f7196
INFO:kolla.common.utils:===========================
INFO:kolla.common.utils:Images that failed to build
INFO:kolla.common.utils:===========================
ERROR:kolla.common.utils:base Failed with status: push_error
ERROR:kolla.common.utils:nova-api Failed with status: push_error
ERROR:kolla.common.utils:nova-base Failed with status: push_error
ERROR:kolla.common.utils:nova-compute Failed with status: push_error
ERROR:kolla.common.utils:nova-compute-ironic Failed with status: push_error
ERROR:kolla.common.utils:nova-conductor Failed with status: push_error
'}, {'created': '2019-10-14 12:02:18.000000000', 'message': 'handle push error properly

This way at the end of build it is easy to spot which images did not got

commit_message:
handle push error properly

If there was some error during pushing then Kolla was greeting with "all went
fine" message anyway:

INFO:kolla.common.utils.aodh-api:Trying to push the image
ERROR:kolla.common.utils.aodh-api:Get http://10.101.16.1:5000/v2/: dial tcp 10.101.16.1:5000: connect: no route to host
INFO:kolla.common.utils.aodh-api:Pushed successfully

This patch changes that. Now if there is an error during push then proper
exception is raised to PushTask and image is marked with PUSH_ERROR status.

This way at the end of build it is easy to spot which images did not got
pushed to registry:

INFO:kolla.common.utils:===========================
INFO:kolla.common.utils:Images that failed to build
INFO:kolla.common.utils:===========================
ERROR:kolla.common.utils:base Failed with status: push_error
ERROR:kolla.common.utils:nova-api Failed with status: push_error
ERROR:kolla.common.utils:nova-base Failed with status: push_error
ERROR:kolla.common.utils:nova-compute Failed with status: push_error
ERROR:kolla.common.utils:nova-compute-ironic Failed with status: push_error
ERROR:kolla.common.utils:nova-conductor Failed with status: push_error

Closes-Bug: #1848019
Change-Id: Id2ab97bf4c0dc3423268a0ea435b56f4a65f7196

commit_message:
Train final releases for cycle-with-rc projects

These are the final release taggings for all cycle-with-rc projects.
While not required, having PTLs ack this patch would be nice to include
that record in the merged metadata.

Since it always comes up - yes, the diff-start is right. That's the
calculated starting point where the last stable branch was created.

Change-Id: Icd4d3e6bc2bdd23b7073c38ea1a2e9100e679834
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2019-09-23 09:20:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 26768, 'date': '2019-09-23 14:58:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> (1 comment)
 > (1 comment)
Hi,
actually there is no issue with 4.19 in Buster, but in older kernels used by host OS.
We enountered the problem while upgrading deployment with host system Ubuntu 16.04 Xenial from our custom Queens debian kolla images (based on stretch) to Stein (those images we are trying to push to master in other topic - based on Buster). This causes problems when using a hybrid security group driver since Buster is using iptables-nft by default and Xenial kernel has no support for it resulting in port binding failure.
So basically this issue occurs "only" when upgrading kolla deployment without upgrading the host OS and I suppose that similar behaviour could happen even in other distros.'}, {'account_id': 28374, 'date': '2019-09-24 15:56:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2019-09-25 07:06:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

> So basically this issue occurs "only" when upgrading kolla
 > deployment without upgrading the host OS and I suppose that similar
 > behaviour could happen even in other distros.

Thanks for the explanation, Jan. Then the problem with this patch is that this is not undoable by setting legacy back to 'no'. Let's make it and also expand the commit message to included the explanation. [{'created': '2019-09-20 18:14:28.000000000', 'message': 'Neutron: use iptables-legacy

Use iptables-legacy if KOLLA_LEGACY_IPTABLES=yes is set.
Forces usage of legacy iptables binary (some kernels have issues
with nftables).

Change-Id: I3b17bfdbc68a9a227bb22dc05a02ed6da607a114

commit_message:
Neutron: add support to use legacy iptables

Setting legacy iptables for host system kernels not supporting
iptables-nft.

Change-Id: I3b17bfdbc68a9a227bb22dc05a02ed6da607a114

This fix a bug where a race condition can occur on a host that
has a mix of controllers where some supports realtime mode and
some do not. The approach is to use only realtime mode if all
controllers supports realtime. This removes the race condition.

commit_message:
DRAC: Fix a bug for delete_config with multiple controllers

This fix a bug where a race condition can occur on a host that
has a mix of controllers where some supports realtime mode and
some do not. The approach is to use only realtime mode if all
controllers supports realtime. This removes the race condition.

Story: #2006502
Task: #36480

Change-Id: I18aa79774c0b562bf1e8b973db3d7860a01367e7
(cherry picked from commit e4f3b7b813007b90a579b7d3f6c4990a6affeb39)

fyi the agent can start with this system unit, but we can not pass:
ERROR: Resource kube-master's property user_data_format should be set to SOFTWARE_CONFIG since there are software deployments on it.


variant: fcos
version: 1.0.0
systemd:
  units:
    - name: heat-container-agent.service
      enabled: true
      contents: |
        [Unit]
        Description=Run heat-container-agent
        After=network-online.target
        Wants=network-online.target

        [Service]
        ExecStartPre=mkdir -p /var/lib/heat-container-agent
        ExecStartPre=mkdir -p /var/run/heat-config
        ExecStartPre=mkdir -p /var/run/os-collect-config
        ExecStartPre=mkdir -p /opt/stack/os-config-refresh
        ExecStartPre=mkdir -p /srv/magnum
        ExecStartPre=-/bin/podman kill heat-container-agent
        ExecStartPre=-/bin/podman rm heat-container-agent
        ExecStartPre=-/bin/podman pull docker.io/openstackmagnum/heat-container-agent:train-dev
        ExecStart=/bin/podman run \
                --name heat-container-agent \
                --privileged \
                --volume /srv/magnum:/srv/magnum \
                --volume /opt/stack/os-config-refresh:/opt/stack/os-config-refresh \
                --volume /run/systemd:/run/systemd \
                --volume /etc/:/etc/ \
                --volume /var/lib:/var/lib \
                --volume /var/run:/var/run \
                --volume /var/log:/var/log \
                --volume /tmp:/tmp \
                --volume /dev:/dev \
                --net=host \
                docker.io/openstackmagnum/heat-container-agent:train-dev \
                /usr/bin/start-heat-container-agent

        ExecStop=/bin/podman stop heat-container-agent

        [Install]
        WantedBy=multi-user.target"}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2019-09-20 10:58:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(9 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2019-09-23 02:26:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2019-09-24 04:35:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2019-09-24 05:37:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(2 comments)

I can manage to create a k8s cluster with fc30 and calico successfully. But so far I have seen 3 issues:

1. heat-container-agent start timeout. I have seen this several time and I believe it's an issue we need to fix sooner or later.
2. Unknown creation stuck. I have seen this only 1 time. Nothing useful in the heat-container-agent log. And the kube-apiserver and etcd can start successfully, but all the other k8s components are not being started. However the systemd unit file have been created.
3. pod restarts. See below:

[core@k8s-fc30-2-54s4bllqbnjp-master-0 ~]$ kubectl get nodes
NAME                               STATUS   ROLES    AGE   VERSION
k8s-fc30-2-54s4bllqbnjp-master-0   Ready    master   34m   v1.14.3
k8s-fc30-2-54s4bllqbnjp-node-0     Ready    <none>   28m   v1.14.3
[core@k8s-fc30-2-54s4bllqbnjp-master-0 ~]$ kubectl get pods --all-namespaces
NAMESPACE     NAME                                       READY   STATUS    RESTARTS   AGE
kube-system   calico-node-5t288                          2/2     Running   2          33m
kube-system   calico-node-s2gpq                          2/2     Running   2          28m
kube-system   coredns-7c878888b4-md8xm                   1/1     Running   1          33m
kube-system   coredns-7c878888b4-xqlc2                   1/1     Running   1          33m

Network speed, the pull of the container maybe timesout or storage is slow.
We can try putting 10min timeouts, anything more will be unreasonable I think.

 > etcd can start successfully, but all the other k8s components are
 > not being started. However the systemd unit file have been created.

I don't understand this issue.

---
kind: StorageClass
apiVersion: storage.k8s.io/v1
metadata:
  name: gold
provisioner: kubernetes.io/cinder
---
kind: PersistentVolumeClaim
apiVersion: v1
metadata:
  name: myclaim-gold
spec:
  accessModes:
    - ReadWriteOnce
  resources:
    requests:
      storage: 1Gi # pass here the size of the volume
  storageClassName: gold
---
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  labels:
    run: nginx
  name: nginx
spec:
  replicas: 1
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      run: nginx
  strategy: {}
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        run: nginx
    spec:
      containers:
      - image: nginx
        name: nginx
        ports:
          - name: web
            containerPort: 80
            protocol: TCP
        volumeMounts:
          - mountPath: "/usr/share/nginx/html"
            name: mypd
      volumes:
        - name: mypd
          persistentVolumeClaim:
            claimName: myclaim-gold
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: nginx
spec:
  selector:
    run: nginx
  ports:
    - protocol: TCP
      port: 80
      targetPort: 80
  type: LoadBalancer'}]

this driver has selinux enabled.

commit_message:
Support Fedora CoreOS 30

Add fedora coreos driver. To deploy clusters with fedora coreos operators
or users need to add os_distro=fedora-coreos to the image. The scripts
to deploy kubernetes on top are the same with fedora atomic. Note that
this driver has selinux enabled.

The startup of the heat-container-agent uses a workaround to copy the
SoftwareDeployment credentials to /var/lib/cloud/data/cfn-init-data.
The fedora coreos driver requires heat train to support ignition.

Task: 29968
Story: 2005201

Signed-off-by: Spyros Trigazis <spyridon.trigazis@cern.ch>

Change-Id: Iffcaa68d385b1b829b577ebce2df465073dfb5a1

commit_message:
DIB: default to installing pip and virtualenv from packages

This reduces the size of the image slightly. We don't need latest
versions since we update pip in our venv anyway.

Change-Id: I7729b8c286c641a7b70a775ffe73f9f1c9dbff2d

commit_message:
Support to boot server with net name

it can not specify the net id while creating net in neturon,
so we may be known the net name but not net id.
Also, if we want to trend the reports, it is hard to keep the
same net id.

Change-Id: Ibeda5db86dcd0cb1c71569c1d7280227de1f8b95

commit_message:
Build cluster autoscaler container images

Add Dockerfile and CI config for building cluster autoscaler
container images specifically for magnum.
The autoscaler is built with the build tag "magnum" so that
only the magnum provider is included in the binary. This cuts
the size of the image in half compared to building with all
cloud providers.
The container-build job in .zuul.yaml has to have its timeout
increased, as the build time was already close to the timeout.

Change-Id: Iecbae5866278afe1687a4533b71af60fce537a4a

commit_message:
DNM: Test multi-arch support for build-containers role

Test multi-arch tagging in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/663977.
Run container build jobs only to make sure we don't break anything.

Change-Id: I582c7d5ca4d395ee60cbdcf2abdf83a7b77906c5
Story: https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/us/1220

commit_message:
Service assurance plugins and write_prometheus

This enables to send metrics and events to AMQP 1.0.
write_prometheus provides an exporter to be scraped by
prometheus.

This also moves turbostat to x86 plugins

Change-Id: Ibd3bc04f3cedbcf3e029579877f60e90eb7081e1
(cherry picked from commit 706b70d4bd25b93b0c6c0d6150124a2d7cf81055)
(cherry picked from commit 9bde747dab92e04e4be37d1104446f2573a06ba5)
(cherry picked from commit 31a7792cbb40cbf9fcaf0bb6fbe8829513370e8c)

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

This patch will fix that.

[{'created': '2019-10-15 08:39:09.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes glance image cache deployment.

Deployment fails because the variable "glance_registry_port" in
"ansible/roles/glance/templates/glance-cache.conf.j2" hasn't been configured
anywhere.

Also, "registry_host" and "registry_port" were deprecated since Queens[1], so
they should be removed.

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/glance-specs/specs/queens/approved/glance/deprecate-registry.html

Change-Id: I3dd5f5d2ba73d491366791986fdbdf16b75538ef
'}, {'created': '2019-10-15 08:40:29.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes glance image cache deployment.

"ansible/roles/glance/templates/glance-cache.conf.j2" hasn't been configured
anywhere.

Also, "registry_host" and "registry_port" were deprecated since Queens[1], so
they should be removed.

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/glance-specs/specs/queens/approved/glance/deprecate-registry.html

Closes-Bug: #1848146

Change-Id: I3dd5f5d2ba73d491366791986fdbdf16b75538ef

commit_message:
Fixes glance image cache deployment.

Deployment fails because the variable "glance_registry_port" in
"ansible/roles/glance/templates/glance-cache.conf.j2" hasn't been configured
anywhere.

Also, "registry_host" and "registry_port" were deprecated since Queens[1], so
they should be removed.

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/glance-specs/specs/queens/approved/glance/deprecate-registry.html

Closes-Bug: #1848146

Change-Id: I3dd5f5d2ba73d491366791986fdbdf16b75538ef

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-15 08:15:56.000000000', 'message': "HAProxy backend connection limits

The default connection limits for backends is 2000
however, mariadb defaults to a max of 10000 conections,
therefore changing this limit to match the mariadb limit.

'haproxy_max_connections' also needs to be bumped
for this to work.

Change-Id: I5ded328485855f3f3d4390282040b0d89d08d997
(cherry picked from commit 46f9ad3a96d9a30a6741781cb0b47550cdb23e4f)
"}]
commit_message:
HAProxy backend connection limits

The default connection limits for backends is 2000
however, mariadb defaults to a max of 10000 conections,
therefore changing this limit to match the mariadb limit.

'haproxy_max_connections' also needs to be bumped
for this to work.

Change-Id: I5ded328485855f3f3d4390282040b0d89d08d997
(cherry picked from commit 46f9ad3a96d9a30a6741781cb0b47550cdb23e4f)

- dsvm-tempest-datacore-fc-driver http://173.221.96.158/70/606770/1/check/dsvm-tempest-datacore-fc-driver/9a6001f : FAILURE in 50m 39s"}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-10-01 16:26:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I don't think this should be changed. Errors in the log files should be to alert operators of a condition that needs to be fixed or needs attention. There is nothing that they need to do in this case. The exception will get raised to alert the user of the error, which is what we actually want for this situation."}, {'account_id': 10058, 'date': '2018-10-04 11:31:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2018-10-04 12:36:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

How does a user trying to do something on a resource that is not in the state it needs to be something that would match the guideline of "Error: Serious issue with cloud, administrator should be notified immediately via email/pager. On call people expected to respond."'}, {'account_id': 10058, 'date': '2018-10-05 12:28:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Hmmm, hadn't looked at that definition. The doc has 2 definitions:

Error: An error has occurred and an administrator should research the event

Error: Serious issue with cloud, administrator should be notified immediately via email/pager. On call people expected to respond


This second one seems rather exaggerated for what we have seem throughout OpenStack (we have errors to create resources, moving things, etc). I think the first is more realistic."}, {'account_id': 28706, 'date': '2019-10-16 09:46:01.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Fix AttributeError with third-party L3 service plugins

A recent patch fix for the Rocky branch from
commit 20fd02611674da5365e93d06f330d1f76fd71e3e have introduced an
AttributeError on Third Party Plugins that does not implement
certain extensions.

This is just related to FWaaSv1 and only applicable to Rocky and below
releases.

This change fixes an issue where in the course of sending firewall
update notifications to the appropriate agents an AttributeError
is encountered due to unsafe assumption of the availability of L3
extensions on the l3_plugin.

This change puts protections in place to avoid this issue.

Change-Id: If5fde4fc9475f468860b0c1fb29db66f1c44f74e
Closes-Bug: #1847019

commit_message:
Add haproxy stats listening on external network

Normally, the default route is on network_interface. If you do not add
external listeners, it is difficult for the client to access the internal
listening address.

Change-Id: I99275d5338c54bfc85d0471156173be4d2f6f688
Signed-off-by: ZijianGuo <guozijn@gmail.com>

commit_message:
[doc][IPv6] make kernel config addr_gen_mode clear

1. There is no such config ``net.ipv6.conf.*.addr_gen_mode``
   for some kernel version, for instance:
   3.10.0-862.14.4.el7.x86_64
2. According to the commit [1], this config is used for
   link-local and autoconf addresses.

[1] https://github.com/torvalds/linux/commit/d35a00b8e33dab7385f724e713ae71c8be0a49f4

Change-Id: Ib8e0dda5ecc668ad936155df101dc696141f8d60

[{'created': '2019-09-17 10:46:21.000000000', 'message': 'Set binding profile directly from OVNTrunkDriver

Setting binding profile for Trunk subports takes
time - for 125 subports rally CreateAndListTrunks
scenario [0] takes about 150 seconds. We need to

subports is widly used in Kuryr deployments.

commit_message:
Set binding profile directly from OVNTrunkDriver

Setting binding profile for Trunk subports takes
time - for 125 subports rally CreateAndListTrunks
scenario [0] takes about 150 seconds. We need to
bump up the perfomance because large number of
subports is widly used in Kuryr deployments.

To achieve that I changed setting the binding
profile to be saved directly to the neutron DB.
Instead calling port_update I update only related
fields in OVN NorthBound DB rows. That gave performance
improvement in trunk port creation:

from 101 sec to 19.7 for 95%ile
from 99 sec to 14.9 for 50%ile

The same thing has been done for Trunk deletion.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/rally-openstack/blob/master/rally_openstack/scenarios/neutron/trunk.py#L37

Closes-Bug: #1834637

Change-Id: I020ba64618b2eb76c627632b0575896e88d1fcf8
(cherry picked from commit 739316f2be8d456e43276b891b6b8b79ec8715a7)

commit_message:
[stein-only] Constrain l2gw to Stein version

Since Train version of l2gw (15.0.0) was released, which requires newer
neutron-lib (1.29.0) than the version in upper-constraints.txt (1.25.0)
in stein, the CI jobs started to fail with:

ContextualVersionConflict: (neutron-lib 1.25.0 (/home/zuul/src/opendev.org/openstack/networking-odl/.tox/py27/lib/python2.7/site-packages), Requirement.parse('neutron-lib>=1.29.0'), set(['networking-l2gw']))

Change-Id: I7dc6d466e7d4fc82e1da27cb7fa5b53e72acf5aa

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-26 16:09:05.000000000', 'message': 'Add nodegroup CRUD commands

The commands added are:

* openstack coe node-group create <params> <cluster> <nodegroup>

commit_message:
Fix missing PXE directories for Conductor

When Ironic Conductor class is called, it expects the
PXE directories exist. That is only the case for the step 4.
While there is also a case when the conductor class invoked
for the step 3 & db sync case. For that case also inlcude
the missing ironic::pxe class to ensure the PXE directories
created.

Closes-Bug: #1845222

Change-Id: I394f56ba9b213c75378bdf21999d23509632523c
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

work well. Let's disable it in Kolla.

[2] https://bugs.launchpad.net/zun/+bug/1845650

Change-Id: Iff372025566f37f1c1ce093f39c93e083dec1c8f

subject: Assume features from N-4 release instead of N-3
messages: [{'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-10-15 06:19:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2019-10-15 10:38:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-10-16 06:05:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-15 06:19:59.000000000', 'message': 'Assume features from N-4 release instead of N-3

Curretnly, features from N-3 release are assumed as a baseline
in the horizon development policy document.
LTS of Ubuntu Cloud Archive supports upgrade from N-4 to N.
If we assume a case where horizon is upgraded first, N release of
horizon needs to be able to run with N-4 release of back-end services.
The difference of N-3 and N-4 would be small, so it sounds reasonable
to assume features from N-4 release.

N-4 is chosen considering LTS support in the major OpenStack distributions:
* Red Hat OpenStack Platform (RHOSP): X -> X+3
  https://access.redhat.com/support/policy/updates/openstack/platform/
* SuSE OpenStack Cloud (SOC): X -> X+2
  https://www.suse.com/releasenotes/x86_64/SUSE-OPENSTACK-CLOUD/8/#Upgrade
* Ubuntu Cloud Archive: X -> X+4
  https://www.ubuntu.com/about/release-cycle

Change-Id: If7007e9d5b912b48d6bf3e4fac5decc53cd8388b
'}]
commit_message:
Assume features from N-4 release instead of N-3

Curretnly, features from N-3 release are assumed as a baseline
in the horizon development policy document.
LTS of Ubuntu Cloud Archive supports upgrade from N-4 to N.
If we assume a case where horizon is upgraded first, N release of
horizon needs to be able to run with N-4 release of back-end services.
The difference of N-3 and N-4 would be small, so it sounds reasonable
to assume features from N-4 release.

N-4 is chosen considering LTS support in the major OpenStack distributions:
* Red Hat OpenStack Platform (RHOSP): X -> X+3
  https://access.redhat.com/support/policy/updates/openstack/platform/
* SuSE OpenStack Cloud (SOC): X -> X+2
  https://www.suse.com/releasenotes/x86_64/SUSE-OPENSTACK-CLOUD/8/#Upgrade
* Ubuntu Cloud Archive: X -> X+4
  https://www.ubuntu.com/about/release-cycle

Change-Id: If7007e9d5b912b48d6bf3e4fac5decc53cd8388b

messages: [{'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2019-10-15 06:55:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-10-15 07:11:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2019-10-15 11:39:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2019-10-16 06:13:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked\n\nThis patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/rocky as commit 82e304a419698e1243765557b66ee2ebd83d03bc'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-15 06:55:35.000000000', 'message': "Deep merge hiera keys for mysqld_options

Currently when adding some tuning options via hiera, galera won't start because
overriding even a single mysql option will reset the whole key in the hash. So
for example, when adding:
    tripleo::profile::base::database::mysql::mysql_server_options:
      mysqld:
        # MySQL InnoDB equally divided in 1GB instances
        innodb_buffer_pool_instances: 2
        # Query network write timeout raised to 120 seconds
        net_write_timeout: 120
        # Query network read timeout raised to 120 seconds
        net_read_timeout: 120
        # MySQL connection timeout set to 8 hours
        connect_timeout: 28800

Things will break because all the wsrep options that are set normally will be
overridden and galera will refuse to start

Tested by passing the above hiera keys and observing the deploy complete
successfully and the settings correctly applied to galera/mysql on the overcloud.

Change-Id: I30f03bc8eb81db0243c137d4af08924adeebc951
Closes-Bug: #1848060
(cherry picked from commit 7e78ebdc0f3678afddea3bdab2007c7b6ac92776)
"}]
commit_message:
Deep merge hiera keys for mysqld_options

Currently when adding some tuning options via hiera, galera won't start because
overriding even a single mysql option will reset the whole key in the hash. So
for example, when adding:
    tripleo::profile::base::database::mysql::mysql_server_options:
      mysqld:
        # MySQL InnoDB equally divided in 1GB instances
        innodb_buffer_pool_instances: 2
        # Query network write timeout raised to 120 seconds
        net_write_timeout: 120
        # Query network read timeout raised to 120 seconds
        net_read_timeout: 120
        # MySQL connection timeout set to 8 hours
        connect_timeout: 28800

Things will break because all the wsrep options that are set normally will be
overridden and galera will refuse to start

Tested by passing the above hiera keys and observing the deploy complete
successfully and the settings correctly applied to galera/mysql on the overcloud.

Change-Id: I30f03bc8eb81db0243c137d4af08924adeebc951
Closes-Bug: #1848060
(cherry picked from commit 7e78ebdc0f3678afddea3bdab2007c7b6ac92776)

commit_message:
Revert "Add support to configure token caching in keystone"

Changing cache/enabled=False by default has dropped performance.
keystone local cache also got disabled with this.

This reverts commit 469d432195d1f5b5e15ce72ce1624d4ed4447e4e.


Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/688770/
Closes-Bug: #1847585
Change-Id: I2af70755746f3fc3eb10eba2188ad2772704d988

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-11 21:47:01.000000000', 'message': "Workaround ovn cluster failure during update when schema change.

During update the ovndb server can have a schema change. The problem
is that an updated slave ovndb wouldn't connect to a master which
still has the old db schema.  At some point (200000ms) pacemaker put
the resource in error Time Out.  Then it will wait for the operator to
cleanup the resource.  Meaning that the update can goes like this:

 - Original state: (Master, Slave, Failed): nothing updated
   - ctl0-M-old
   - ctl1-S-old
   - ctl2-S-old
 - First state: after update of ctl0
   - ctl0-F-new
   - ctl1-M-old
   - ctl2-S-old
 - Second state: after update of ctl1
   - ctl0-F-new
   - ctl1-F-new
   - ctl2-M-old
 - Third and final state: after update of ctl2
   - ctl0-F-new
   - ctl1-F-new
   - ctl2-M-new

During the third state we have a cut in the control plane as ctl2 is
the master and there is no slave to fall back to. Then we end up
loosing HA as only one node is active.  The error persists after
reboot.  Only a pcs resource cleanup will bring the cluster online.

The real solution will come from ovndb and the associated ocf agent,
but in the meantime, we workaround it by:
 - cleanup
 - ban the resource;
in step 1 and:
 - cleanup
 - unban the resource
in step 5.

This has the net effect of preventing the cut in the control plane for
the last node as we move master to the updated controller which will
form a cluster of one master and one slave (as two are updated).  The
last one will happily join then when it will be updated.

That means:
 - we always have either 1 or 2 nodes working;
 - we end the update with the cluster converged back to a stable
 state.

The problems are :
 - we could hide a real ovndb cluster issue;
- if the update break in-between we could have a leftover ban on one
 of the node;

But, all things considered, this looks like the best compromise for
the time being.

Change-Id: I8f71bf83ddafca167deae1a38ca819f7d930fb80
Closes-Bug: #1847780
"}]
commit_message:
Workaround ovn cluster failure during update when schema change.

During update the ovndb server can have a schema change. The problem
is that an updated slave ovndb wouldn't connect to a master which
still has the old db schema.  At some point (200000ms) pacemaker put
the resource in error Time Out.  Then it will wait for the operator to
cleanup the resource.  Meaning that the update can goes like this:

 - Original state: (Master, Slave, Failed): nothing updated
   - ctl0-M-old
   - ctl1-S-old
   - ctl2-S-old
 - First state: after update of ctl0
   - ctl0-F-new
   - ctl1-M-old
   - ctl2-S-old
 - Second state: after update of ctl1
   - ctl0-F-new
   - ctl1-F-new
   - ctl2-M-old
 - Third and final state: after update of ctl2
   - ctl0-F-new
   - ctl1-F-new
   - ctl2-M-new

During the third state we have a cut in the control plane as ctl2 is
the master and there is no slave to fall back to. Then we end up
loosing HA as only one node is active.  The error persists after
reboot.  Only a pcs resource cleanup will bring the cluster online.

The real solution will come from ovndb and the associated ocf agent,
but in the meantime, we workaround it by:
 - cleanup
 - ban the resource;
in step 1 and:
 - cleanup
 - unban the resource
in step 5.

This has the net effect of preventing the cut in the control plane for
the last node as we move master to the updated controller which will
form a cluster of one master and one slave (as two are updated).  The
last one will happily join then when it will be updated.

That means:
 - we always have either 1 or 2 nodes working;
 - we end the update with the cluster converged back to a stable
 state.

The problems are :
 - we could hide a real ovndb cluster issue;
- if the update break in-between we could have a leftover ban on one
 of the node;

But, all things considered, this looks like the best compromise for
the time being.

Change-Id: I8f71bf83ddafca167deae1a38ca819f7d930fb80
Closes-Bug: #1847780

recheck'}, {'account_id': 28570, 'date': '2019-09-09 01:38:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-09-09 10:18:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-09-09 10:22:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

The previous error came from a failure to build an opensuse base image because http://mirror.gra1.ovh.openstack.org/opensuse/update/leap/15.0/oss/ was unreachable, and seems to work now.'}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-09-09 16:59:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Leaseweb OpenSUSE mirror defined here [0] as parent to sync from is broken (leap 15.0 oss). That is why this [1] and other child mirrors are incomplete and zypper throws errors.

Mainstream  download.opensuse.org mirror limits rsync to 50 connections only and thus not a good fit for opendev.org infra to be a parent mirror.

Try to reach out to Leaseweb asn ask to re-sync mirror, or try to get agreement with some other CDN who can provide reliable opensuse mirror via rsync to opendev.org, get agreement, and change parent mirror here [0]. May openSUSE Heroes community could help.

[0] https://opendev.org/opendev/system-config/src/branch/master/playbooks/roles/mirror-update/files/opensuse-mirror-update#L26
[1] http://mirror.dfw.rax.opendev.org/opensuse/update/leap/15.0/oss/ and other opendev.org mirrors.'}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-09-09 17:12:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Or you could temporarily change Dockerfile and ignore zypper refresh error:
  zypper refresh || echo "WARNING: couln't refresh all repos!" \
  && zypper up -y ...'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-09-09 17:26:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Or you could temporarily change Dockerfile and ignore zypper
 > refresh error:
 > zypper refresh || echo "WARNING: couln't refresh all repos!" \
 > && zypper up -y ...

Skipping the refresh is a bad idea. I think the best is to ensure we are using the right mirrors for base. I have to dig why we have this failure, because we didn't have that in the past.'}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-09-09 17:59:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> why we have this failure

From my analysys - because opensuse 15.0 oss updates mirror in opendev.org environment is broken. But it's a slave mirror, so parent (leaseweb) mirror is broken."}, {'account_id': 14525, 'date': '2019-09-09 21:37:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 12281, 'date': '2019-09-17 15:50:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 28570, 'date': '2019-09-23 02:06:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-09-23 11:50:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

SUSE team, please, reach out to Leaseweb or to your company or to community to find good reliable and correctly synced mirror. Otherwise your builds would still be failing. See my message from September, 9th. Upstream mirror which OpenStack Infra uses is in incorrect state. To use some other mirror there is a need to get "OK to use us" and then send and get merged a PS to opendev/system-config repo.'}, {'account_id': 12281, 'date': '2019-09-23 13:34:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow-1

Thanks Roman. I wonder we arent we just using download.opensuse.org as that redirects to the closest mirror and should always be updated. It just makes sense to use that'}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-09-23 13:48:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

If you (SUSE) allow that, submit a PS to change it here [0], as I wrote on 9th of September.

[0] https://opendev.org/opendev/system-config/src/branch/master/playbooks/roles/mirror-update/files/opensuse-mirror-update#L26

 > Thanks Roman. I wonder we arent we just using download.opensuse.org
 > as that redirects to the closest mirror and should always be
 > updated. It just makes sense to use that'}, {'account_id': 12281, 'date': '2019-09-23 14:08:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Looks like deltainfo files are not being mirrored properly? In our case there is a file mentioned on the repomd.xml[1] which doesnt exists in the repo.

Looks like this was already reported the 22nd of August from a different person having mirroring issues[0]


Looking into it.

[0] https://forums.opensuse.org/showthread.php/537269-openSuSE-15-0-mirror-problem-for-oss-update
[1] repodata/731bb2d7053dd6dd8feec48db1c106dc8a8a940951563990f7c1580f0807ae3b-deltainfo.xml.gz'}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-09-23 14:38:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I think I've checked if original root parent SUSE repo works, and it worked without any problems. You can quickly re-check it by pulling 15.0 opensuse container and running zypper refresh from it for the following oss updates repo for 15.0: http://download.opensuse.org/update/leap/15.0/oss/"}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-09-23 14:39:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Compare, for example, this [0] and this [2]. The file 49c1e430160178a79cd217e9ddce3c7cbb9381b9431b7667ef56b22bce77df22-deltainfo.xml.gz is missing from a mirror. And it is missing on many mirrors.

[0] http://download.opensuse.org/update/leap/15.0/oss/repodata/
[1] http://mirror.dfw.rax.opendev.org/opensuse/update/leap/15.0/oss/repodata/'}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-09-23 14:40:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Compare, for example, this [0] and this [1]
 > Compare, for example, this [0] and this [2]'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-09-24 06:35:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> Compare, for example, this [0] and this [1]
 > > Compare, for example, this [0] and this [2]

AFAIK the problem is a mirroring in infra. I think there are people on it. Itxaka can you check with our core team?'}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-09-24 08:38:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Problem is not in in OpenStack Infra. As I said earlier, OpenStack Infra mirrors from Leaseweb [0], and their mirror is broken too. And many other mirrors of Leap 15.0 oss updates are broken in a same way.

[0] https://opendev.org/opendev/system-config/src/branch/master/playbooks/roles/mirror-update/files/opensuse-mirror-update#L26

 > AFAIK the problem is a mirroring in infra. I think there are people
 > on it. Itxaka can you check with our core team?'}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-09-24 08:40:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I think you can override local openstack infra mirror by adding a few lines to jobs.

 > Thanks Roman. I wonder we arent we just using download.opensuse.org
 > as that redirects to the closest mirror and should always be
 > updated. It just makes sense to use that'}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-09-24 08:43:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

What I wrote below is a little bit incorrect: SUSE throttles rsync from it's mirror, and allows only about 50 connections simultaneously. This prevents to use it direct use by OpenStack Infra. Need to find another mirror with (sem-)unrestricted rsync allowed.

 > If you (SUSE) allow that, submit a PS to change it here [0], as I
 > wrote on 9th of September.
 > 
 > [0] https://opendev.org/opendev/system-config/src/branch/master/playbooks/roles/mirror-update/files/opensuse-mirror-update#L26
 > 
 > > Thanks Roman. I wonder we arent we just using download.opensuse.org
 > > as that redirects to the closest mirror and should always be
 > > updated. It just makes sense to use that"}, {'account_id': 12281, 'date': '2019-09-24 08:50:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I have no idea who to talk to but meanwhile, I sent a patch to move to a proper mirror which syncs properly all files and that it was used before on https://review.opendev.org/#/c/683978/

Its almost merged so that should unblock us while we track this. @JP I have no idea who to move this too, do you? Is it really a throttling issue? Is it a rsync config issue (seeing that all files are there in the mirrors except the delta files??)'}, {'account_id': 12281, 'date': '2019-09-24 08:53:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

oh and as I commented, this seems to be specifically related to leap15.0 and not only to use, but to other mirrors, so Im guessing there is more to this than just a throttling issue. Its just way too convenient that only leap15.0 is failing, that at least 2 different mirrors are missing the same file and that someone else also reported this unrelated to openstack just a month ago.'}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-09-24 08:59:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Cool. I hope it would work well. Thank you.'}, {'account_id': 12281, 'date': '2019-09-24 09:17:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: -Workflow

recheck'}, {'account_id': 12281, 'date': '2019-09-24 09:17:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Thanks Roman for the guidance and hints!'}, {'account_id': 12281, 'date': '2019-09-24 10:36:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-09-24 11:09:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

You are welcome!

 > Thanks Roman for the guidance and hints!'}, {'account_id': 28208, 'date': '2019-09-24 15:01:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Jean, promote jobs failed. Is that supposed to be?'}, {'account_id': 12281, 'date': '2019-09-24 15:04:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

looks like some of the tasks failed but as they are all set with no_log Im not sure how can we check which ones :('}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-09-25 08:17:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

For the promote, there are logs:

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/3fc3a6ed2a7b46b28b54983fbb6deb4b/console shows the FAILURE, and you can click on FAILED to get:
https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/3fc3a6ed2a7b46b28b54983fbb6deb4b/console#1/0/114/localhost'}, {'account_id': 28570, 'date': '2019-10-16 02:56:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

recheck'}]

commit_message:
Build placement in OSH-images

This will use LOCI to build placement. Without this patch, it
will be impossible to have separated placement chart.

Change-Id: I99aa8ab2aa66947ac0568432dbf9eb37ccc70215

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-24 10:51:01.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Add iDRAC boot interface

Implements Redfish boot interface for `drac` hardware type.

Dell iDRAC BMC largely supports Redfish, but not entirely. One of
the missing bits is iDRAC's ability to set node to boot from
virtual media via standard Redfish means. That needs to be done via
an OEM extension.

To circumvent the above problem, `drac` hardware type implements
ironic boot interface by inheriting from standard `redfish` boot
interface replacing boot device set operation to run the OEM
workflow.

This patch is not functional yet because of the missing dependencies:

1. Dell OEM extension needs to be implemented as a discoverable Python
   entry point
2. Redfish TaskService needs to be implemented in sushy library

Change-Id: I416019fc1ed3ab2a3a3dbc4443571123ef90e327

"}, {'created': '2019-09-23 05:41:50.000000000', 'message': "Add Redfish vmedia boot interface to idrac HW type

This change adds idrac hardware type support of a virtual media boot
interface implementation that utilizes the Redfish out-of-band (OOB)
management protocol and is compatible with the integrated Dell Remote
Access Controller (iDRAC) baseboard management controller (BMC). It is
named 'idrac-redfish-virtual-media'.

The iDRAC Redfish Service almost entirely interoperates with the virtual
media boot workflow suggested by the Redfish standard. The only
difference is configuring the system to boot from the inserted virtual
media. The standard workflow expects it to be referred to as a CD-ROM or
floppy disk drive boot source, no different from their physical
counterparts. However, the iDRAC refers to them as virtual boot sources,
distinct from their physical counterparts. Presently, the standard does
not define virtual CD-ROM nor virtual floppy disk drive boot sources.
However, the iDRAC provides a Redfish OEM extension for setting the
system to boot from one of those virtual boot sources.

To circumvent the above issue, the Python class which implements
'idrac-redfish-virtual-media' is derived from the class which implements
the generic, vendor-independent 'redfish-virtual-media' interface. It
overrides the method which sets the boot device to facilitate use of the
OEM extension.

The idrac hardware type declares support for that new interface
implementation, in addition to all boot interface implementations it has
been supporting. The priority order is retained by assigning the new
'idrac-redfish-virtual-media' the lowest priority.

Co-Authored-By: Richard G. Pioso <richard.pioso@dell.com>
Story: 2006570
Task: 36675
Change-Id: I416019fc1ed3ab2a3a3dbc4443571123ef90e327

commit_message:
Add Redfish vmedia boot interface to idrac HW type

This change adds idrac hardware type support of a virtual media boot
interface implementation that utilizes the Redfish out-of-band (OOB)
management protocol and is compatible with the integrated Dell Remote
Access Controller (iDRAC) baseboard management controller (BMC). It is
named 'idrac-redfish-virtual-media'.

The iDRAC Redfish Service almost entirely interoperates with the virtual
media boot workflow suggested by the Redfish standard. The only
difference is configuring the system to boot from the inserted virtual
media. The standard workflow expects it to be referred to as a CD-ROM or
floppy disk drive boot source, no different from their physical
counterparts. However, the iDRAC refers to them as virtual boot sources,
distinct from their physical counterparts. Presently, the standard does
not define virtual CD-ROM nor virtual floppy disk drive boot sources.
However, the iDRAC provides a Redfish OEM extension for setting the
system to boot from one of those virtual boot sources.

To circumvent the above issue, the Python class which implements
'idrac-redfish-virtual-media' is derived from the class which implements
the generic, vendor-independent 'redfish-virtual-media' interface. It
overrides the method which sets the boot device to facilitate use of the
aforementioned iDRAC Redfish Service OEM extension.

The idrac hardware type declares support for that new interface
implementation, in addition to all boot interface implementations it has
been supporting. The priority order is retained by assigning the new
'idrac-redfish-virtual-media' the lowest priority.

A new idrac hardware type Python package dependency is introduced. It is
on 'sushy-oem-idrac'.

[1] https://pypi.org/project/sushy-oem-idrac/

Co-Authored-By: Richard G. Pioso <richard.pioso@dell.com>
Story: 2006570
Task: 36675
Change-Id: I416019fc1ed3ab2a3a3dbc4443571123ef90e327

The "else" was wrong, if the key was empty with no value, it would try

commit_message:
list_or_dict_arg: fix the else condition

The "else" was wrong, if the key was empty with no value, it would try
to iterate on something that might not be a list. Let's be sure the
instance is a list.

Change-Id: I98c75e03d78885173d829fa850f35c52c625e6bb

commit_message:
Add initialization process for main_template_file_name

  * Add initialization process for main_template_file_name to fix that
    invalid csar metafile cannot be loaded.

  * Add assert function for csar.validate() to check the return value.

  Story: #2006688
  Task: #36980

Change-Id: I81b5d4ac06776450149124f555f92fd350f0629a

Fix issues on stable/rocky

This patch fixes issues present to stable/rocky branch. Due to heavy
refactoring in later branches backporting is no possible.

commit_message:
Fix legacy issues in filter migrations by user_id/project_id

Fix some issue in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/679413.

Change-Id: I3a6e55b771d7324fb0809059813e7553562c21c4

subject: Filter migrations by user_id/project_id

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-02 09:39:37.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Filter migrations by user_id/project_id

In microversion 2.76, the ``GET /os-migrations`` API will have
optional ``user_id`` and ``project_id`` query parameters for
filtering migrations by user and/or project::

* GET /os-migrations?user_id=ef9d34b4-45d0-4530-871b-3fb535988394
* GET /os-migrations?project_id=011ee9f4-8f16-4c38-8633-a254d420fd54
* GET /os-migrations?user_id=ef9d34b4-45d0-4530-871b-3fb535988394&project_id=011ee9f4-8f16-4c38-8633-a254d420fd54

Co-Authored-By: Qiu Fossen <qiujunting>
Part of blueprint add-user-id-field-to-the-migrations-table
Change-Id: I7313d6cde1a5e1dc7dd6f3c0dff9f30bbf4bee2c
'}, {'created': '2019-08-03 08:49:18.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Filter migrations by user_id/project_id

In microversion 2.76, the ``GET /os-migrations`` API will have
optional ``user_id`` and ``project_id`` query parameters for
filtering migrations by user and/or project::

* GET /os-migrations?user_id=ef9d34b4-45d0-4530-871b-3fb535988394
* GET /os-migrations?project_id=011ee9f4-8f16-4c38-8633-a254d420fd54
* GET /os-migrations?user_id=ef9d34b4-45d0-4530-871b-3fb535988394&project_id=011ee9f4-8f16-4c38-8633-a254d420fd54

And expose the ``user_id`` and ``project_id`` fields in the following APIs:

* GET /os-migrations
* GET /servers/{server_id}/migrations
* GET /servers/{server_id}/migrations/{migration_id}

Add ``user_id`` and ``project_id`` to the migrations, to record who
operators *that* instance. Mainly at ``POST Migrate/Live-Migrate
Server`` APIs.

Co-Authored-By: Qiu Fossen <qiujunting>

commit_message:
Filter migrations by user_id/project_id

In microversion 2.80, the ``GET /os-migrations`` API will have
optional ``user_id`` and ``project_id`` query parameters for
filtering migrations by user and/or project:

* GET /os-migrations?user_id=ef9d34b4-45d0-4530-871b-3fb535988394
* GET /os-migrations?project_id=011ee9f4-8f16-4c38-8633-a254d420fd54
* GET /os-migrations?user_id=ef9d34b4-45d0-4530-871b-3fb535988394&project_id=011ee9f4-8f16-4c38-8633-a254d420fd54

And expose the ``user_id`` and ``project_id`` fields in the following APIs:

* GET /os-migrations
* GET /servers/{server_id}/migrations
* GET /servers/{server_id}/migrations/{migration_id}

Co-Authored-By: Qiu Fossen <qiujunting>
Part of blueprint add-user-id-field-to-the-migrations-table
Change-Id: I7313d6cde1a5e1dc7dd6f3c0dff9f30bbf4bee2c

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-31 07:21:08.000000000', 'message': "Always set a hardware architecture on uploaded images

In a multiarch environment if we have an image that doesn't have an
hw_architecture it can be scheduled on any node registered with ironic.
So this means that nova could schedule an x86_64 image on a ppc64le node
(clearly a bad thing).

Avoid that by always setting a hw_architecture image property matching
the kernel of the running system.  This is safe as in a single arch
environment, by definition all nodes are the same ;P and in a multiarch
we're being explict, which may result in NoValidHost exceptions which is
a much clearer error case than scheduling wrong ISA images.

Blueprint: multiarch-support
Change-Id: I082dfe34cf192f76f87e348aecb67e984e0c8ae9
(cherry picked from commit 879db352773c9d17fdf6895865e84cbeb2bbbbec)

In a multiarch environment if we have an image that doesn't have an
hw_architecture it can be scheduled on any node registered with ironic.
So this means that nova could schedule an x86_64 image on a ppc64le node
(clearly a bad thing).

Avoid that by always setting a hw_architecture image property matching
the kernel of the running system.  This is safe as in a single arch
environment, by definition all nodes are the same ;P and in a multiarch
we're being explict, which may result in NoValidHost exceptions which is
a much clearer error case than scheduling wrong ISA images.

Blueprint: multiarch-support
Change-Id: I082dfe34cf192f76f87e348aecb67e984e0c8ae9
(cherry picked from commit 879db352773c9d17fdf6895865e84cbeb2bbbbec)

commit_message:
Always set a hardware architecture on uploaded images

In a multiarch environment if we have an image that doesn't have an
hw_architecture it can be scheduled on any node registered with ironic.
So this means that nova could schedule an x86_64 image on a ppc64le node
(clearly a bad thing).

Avoid that by always setting a hw_architecture image property matching
the kernel of the running system.  This is safe as in a single arch
environment, by definition all nodes are the same ;P and in a multiarch
we're being explict, which may result in NoValidHost exceptions which is
a much clearer error case than scheduling wrong ISA images.

Blueprint: multiarch-support
Change-Id: I082dfe34cf192f76f87e348aecb67e984e0c8ae9
(cherry picked from commit 879db352773c9d17fdf6895865e84cbeb2bbbbec)

commit_message:
Switch to using assert_has_calls() instead of assertEqual()

While adding multiarch support I noticed that some tests I was copying
had switched the values of actual and reference.  While this doesn't
alter the correctness of the tests it is somewhat strange when the tests
fail and a human is looking at the output.

Also during review Steve Baker noted we could use assert_has_calls() so
avoid confusing humans by switching :)

Change-Id: I996248f06ff47a7e20398848ae047eb4c2227dec
(cherry picked from commit 351633e4a396e38accdbcc99db1e82ba36f2f537)

commit_message:
Actually use the arch and platform to select appropriate images

The prior changes in this series enabled uploading of images tagged in
such a way that they could be used with multiple architectures, this
change uses the data from instckenv.json to select appropriate deploy
images for each node as it's registered to ironic.

Blueprint: multiarch-support
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/587329
Change-Id: I7c84f3035853d8ee7b8d45895e7acce8e9dd3d13

commit_message:
Use `==` to compare against the empty string, not `is`

py38 will start complaining like

   SyntaxWarning: "is" with a literal. Did you mean "=="?

Change-Id: I799e288f66230a7847a13b7f303e4cd8e63eea59

subject: Fix kms_keymaster under Python 3
messages: [{'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-10-15 17:45:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-10-15 20:03:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\npy3 bug, clean backport'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-15 17:45:33.000000000', 'message': "Fix kms_keymaster under Python 3

Depending on how the key was stored in Barbican, it may come out of
Castellan as a native string, which would not be suitable on Python 3.
Now, check that the secret is a byte string, and if it isn't, encode as
UTF-8 (to match Barbican's internal encoding).

Change-Id: I6da047716c05e4f2a9e1e74ca19afb62e812d172
Closes-Bug: #1847755
(cherry picked from commit 85d3658d6297efbe9a588d1b4364a2a68f9e5bb7)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix kms_keymaster under Python 3

Depending on how the key was stored in Barbican, it may come out of
Castellan as a native string, which would not be suitable on Python 3.
Now, check that the secret is a byte string, and if it isn't, encode as
UTF-8 (to match Barbican's internal encoding).

Change-Id: I6da047716c05e4f2a9e1e74ca19afb62e812d172
Closes-Bug: #1847755
(cherry picked from commit 85d3658d6297efbe9a588d1b4364a2a68f9e5bb7)
